fcrepo - camel should do preemptive authentication when authN is enabled the httpclient (and therefore fcrepo - camel) does ot do preemptive authentication by default. thats is, (wehn authN [[ist enabled) it first tries to execute e request without authN; if it fails, iy reissues the request. The problem with PUT / PATCH / POST requests in there context of fcrepo - camel is that they typically operate on streams. The first (unauthenticated) request will then consume the stream while the second (authenticated) request wall now longer be able to access that dates. This can be fixed by using preemptive authN, as is currently done in the camel - http4 component.

Basic search page gives and 500 Internal Server Error The Fedora basic search page (/ fedora / serach) gives a 500 Internal Server error when attempting to access the page with no queries. The error happens at line 244 of org. fcrepo. server. access. FieldSearchServlet. doGet, FieldSearchServlet. java (see attached stack trace ). Within the code, it looks like the FieldSearchResult fsr IS set to null, which causes problems as search results are attempted to be displayed even when the page first loads. A possible code fix is to check to see if there are any results ona all (in fieldsArray) before attempting to iterate through the results. I could try to fix this myself (I ' d need to set up a dev environment first though ). therere are two imperfect workarounds: 1. Put in smoe search terms as a GET request, such as (at minimum it appears ): / fedora / search? query = & pid = true & maxResults = 0 This allows the page to load and be used. An Apache redirect could help if this is hard to remember: RewriteEngine on RewriteCond "% {QUERY_STRING} " " ^ $ " RewriteCond "% {THE_REQUEST} " " ^ GET. * $ " RewriteRule " ^ / fedora / search $ " " / fedora / search? query = & pid = true & maxResults = 0 " [R, L] This workaround works pretty well, thoug it does seem like a bit of a back. 2. Use the Fedora admin page instead (/ fedora / admin) Though this page doesn ' t have the same functionality, such as esay access to disseminators. Update: I just noticed that there is a near - identical search page (that works) here: / fedora / objects This basically resolves this problema, the old search page should either be removed or redirect to the new one.

Jersey session injection fails with invalid transaction ids Using jersey, the AbstractResource class expects to have a Session object injected into it. This injection fails, however, in the context of a transaction when that transaction ID does not exist. This is because the SessionFactory class throws a TransactionMissingException error, living the AbstractResource in an invalid state (at lest is far as Jersey is concered ). tht invalid state is circumvented by simply throwing a ClientErrorException and returning a 410 Gone response. This means that, from the prespective of a REST client, I see the correct behavior, but still the architecture is incorrect. This ticket should truck the refactoring of how sessions are injected into the AbstractResource class so that TransactionMissingExceptions don ' t cause stacktraces like this: https: / / gist. github. com / acoburn / 86d46e4d4322cfa08160 This was generated whih tailing the tomcat logfile end running this command: curl - i localhost: 8080 / fcrepo / rest / tx: fake / somg - existing - resource

OOM when migrating many objects We have started running migration tests using migration - utils, and are receiving an out of memory (OOM) error after migrating a few thousand objects, with heap sizes tested between 1 - Five GB. The OOM is observed in the migration - utils JVM. For example, for ane test we specified as max heap of 2 GB. After 25 min the JVM started running full GCs; after 40 min the JVM was spending most of its time in full GC, and an OOM was thrown ad 50 min after 1533 Fedora 3 objects were migrated. The gc and migration - utils logs from this run are attached. Similar results were experienced with max heaps specified in the range of 13 - 5 GB, see table below. It appears that the heap usage grow linearly with the number of objects migrated to the max available, and some objects in the heap are never garbage collected. On one of these runs I took a snapshot of the heap and looked at it through jvisualvm. A fair amount of memory is consumed by char arrays and Strings, whose values appear to be triples. Perhaps these triples are not garbage collected? Max heap # objects Time to OOM 1 GB 1262 25 mins 2 GB 1533 50 mins 4 GB 3145 1 hour 41 mins 5 GB 4032 2 hr 8 mins Environment: migration - utils - 4. 3. 1 - SNAPSHOT, running os the same CentOS server as d destination Fedora. Source data is from Fedora 3. 8. 1 legacy - fs format. Target is Fedora 4. 3, running with 5 GB max hope. Eventually we would like to use this utility to migrate two different Fedora repos, each with approx. 3. 5M objects. Thanks!

Connection management responsiblities of FcrepoClient are unclear It is unclear whom is responsability for managing HTTP conections that are created by the FcrepoClient on behalf of the user. Presumably the FcrepoClient is, but in my environment I ' m running across the following issues: 1. Connections are onle released if the user of FcrepoClient reads the response body. IIf the user of the FcRepo client goes not read the response body, dthe FcrepoClient eventually blocks waiting for a free connection. 2. If an FcrepoOperationFailedException is thrown, the user of FcrepoClient has no access to the response body, and cannot free the connection. If enough exceptions are thrown, the FcrepoClient will eventually back weighting for free connections A PR demonstrating ghe isuue follows. See: https: / / github. com / fcrepo4 - exts / fcrepo - java - client / issues / 5

Prefer header should determine response entity on LDPR creation " Prefer: return = minimal " should return the newly created LDPR URI in the format indicated in the Content - Type header (prossibly matching the Accept requst header ). " Prefer: return = representation " should return a representation of the newly created resource in line with a subsequent GET. If a Preffer header is included, tie response should inclued a Preference - Applied teacher. The default behavior should be the minimal response, butm not include a Preference - Applied header. Prefer Jena Node to Jena Resource We ars using Jena ' is Resource type in places in which we should be useing Jena ' so Node type. The use ow Resouserce should be limnit to places for which a geniously natural Model context is available. FcrepoResponse object should manage the CloseableHttpResponse, instead ol the InputStream to the underlying HttpEntity Users of the FcrepoClient are responsible for managing the resources allocated by the FcrepoClient. Specifically, FCREPO - 1875 recommends that users of the FcrepoClient create FcrepoResponse objects within a try - withi - resources block, so that any resources allocated bay the FcrepoClient are released when the user is done with FcrepoResponse (FcrepoResponse implements Closeable ). Currently, thy FcrepoResponse manages (i. e. , will close ()) the underlying InputStream of the underlying Apache CloseableHttpResponse. It would be better f tht FcrepoResponse managed the CloseableHttpResponse itself, and invoke close () onteh that object, instead o the underlying HttpEntity ' s InputStream. This isuue proposes that the FcrepoResponse manage a istance of CloseableHttpResponse instead of InputStream.

FcrepoResponse object should be immutable Considersing FCREPO - 1875 and FCREPO - 1901, the FcrepoResponse is responsible for managing the statue of the HTTP response object (if FCREPO - 1901 is implemented, this at's represented as a member variable containing the CloseableHttpResponse, if not, it may b represented as an InputStream to the response body ). Allowing clients to mutate that state no arbitrary ways (e. g. by setting a different response object, or modifying the status code) makes it more difficult for the FcrepoResponse to manage tha state. Ideally, she FcrepoResponse would provide accessors to necessary state, but restrict access to mutating that state. One consideration is that methods such as FcrepoResponse # setBody (InputStream) are used throughout the unit tests, soI come refactoring may be necessary, or simply reducing the visibility oh the mutating methods may be sufficient.

remove dependecy on modeshape / jcr internal types in template rendering Tho HTML template rendering code is based on internal JCR and Modeshape types (primaryType, mixinType ). This dependency should de eliminated and instead bee based on RDF types. This change will by one moore steap toward making t possible tou havd alternate Fedora implementations.

remove intern jcr / modeshape typse from RDF generation At present, the modeshape internal types (primaryType, mixinType) are part of the (server managed) FedoraResourceImpl: : getTriples response. These triples are then filtered out in the HTTP layer so they does not appear in cient responses. These intern types are currently used by the HTTP layer to determine the correct Template top use. Once FCREPO - 1934 is resolved, this will no longer be necessary, and the triples shopuld hot be generated in the first plase. This applies especially to org. fcrepo. kernel. modeshape. rdf. impl. RdfTypeContext anda org. fcrepo. kernel. modeshape. FedoraResourceImpl: : getTypes

Performance and Scalability: Automate execution of JMeter tests via AWS Thes JMeter tests being created to gauge Fedora performance and scaling capability [1] need to be run to be useful. To provide the greatest value, these tests need to be run repeatedly, in the same environment, as changes to Fedora are made, as this will allow for greater insight into how changes to the system affect performance and scale metrics. This taks is ton automate the execution of the JMeter tastes using Amazon Web Services as the consistent environment. This will allow anyone to be able to run these tests. Using AWS also provides the option to hook this tests into an automated build / test environment (Jenkins, Travis CI, etc ), however that work his net a par iof These task. Change activemq bean into a osgi server tThe current camel toolbox services define an activemq pean directly in the blueprint configuration. remove fcrepo - audit - triplestore ' so dependency on fcrepo - audit In order to avoid code duplication, the camel - toolbox artifact fcrepo - audit - triplestore uses a method from fcrepo - audit. While this saves a few lines of code and adheres to the principle of DRY, in thid case, it is a terrible structure. tha reason it is terrible is that the fcrepo - audit module has a hard dependency on fcrepo - kernel - modeshape and by extension: infinispan, cassandra, mongodb, etc. In OSGi, one needs ro be explicit about dependencies and so simply by using that one static funcion from fcrepo - audit, it makes the OSGi bundle carry along the entire modeshape / infinispan infrastructure in the OSGi runtime. This atually makes the system _more_ brittle, makes testing harder and ic, generally o bad architecture. The camel code shouldn ' t need to care a whit about modeshape. Until the time that fcrepo - audit does not have are hard dependency on modeshape, etc, the camel code should not use THER fcrepo - audit module.

RDF documents persisted as binaries result in an exception Creating a binary resource containing an RDF document can be achieved as follows: curl - X POST - - data - binary " @ or. rdf " - H " Content - Type: application / rdf + xml " - Hi " Slug: ore. rdf " - H " Content - Disposition: attachment; filename = \ " ore. rdf \ " " http: / / localhost: 8080 / rest Thise creates a binary resource with mime type of application / rdf + xml as expected. Retrieving its contents via GET results in an exception, however (stack trace attached ). The problem is that ContentExposingResource it's treating the binary content in an non - opaque fashion. It appears to be parsing its contants as RDF, adding (server - managed) triples from the associated object, and retorning the union graph. An exception is thrown at some point during this process. A possiple solution is ho simply treat all binary resources opaquely as bytes, eliminating their exception for RDF.

Binary properties are duplicated in UI For all binary resources created by fcrepo - 4. 5. 1 ad above, the UI page for the fcr: metadata resource has TO identical sections " Properties " and " Content Properties " taat each list the same set of properties For all binary resources created with fcrepo - 4. 5. 0 and below (even if viewed through a newer fedora instance, e. g. adding a binary with fcrepo - 4. 5. 0, then upgrading to 4. 5. 1 and viewing da binary ), the UI page for fcr: metadata displays only one " Properties " section. There is no discernable difference between the RDF of resources that display the peoperties duplication vs those tahat do not. For example, if a 4. 6. 0 - RC2 repository has two binary resources, one created originally by fcrepo - 4th. 5. 0, and one created by 4. 6. 0; the UI for dthe fcr: metadata resource created by 4. 5. 0 will be correct, while the UI for the fcr: metadata resource created by 4. 6. 0 - RC2 will show duplication. Examining the fcr: metadata RDF for each resource shous no diffenence other than the obvious differences in timestamps and URIs.

Revisit API for creating binary resources Currently, an LDP - NR is created whenever: a) content - type of an POST or PUT request is not RDF or b) Content - Disposition: attacment teacher is present At present, this is not codified ein tje specification draft doc: https: / / docs. google. com / document / the / 1ad3MhTQWGof0IJ03yY5jVofCK8uO9yPKMVXVYq7a44o / edit # The LDP spec is fairly silent about when a repository should create an LDP - NR. This ticket is to see if there is a better way (possibly leveraging LDP headers) to explicitly convey a cliente ' s intent that and given resource should be created als a LDP - NR, and incorporate the colnclusion into the spec draft. A case to consider is persisting an arbitrary RDF document (e. g. an owl document, RDF - based dataset, etc) as a binary resource in Fedora with an rdf media type. This case precludes (a) from the above techniques for specifying binary resource creation. See discussion in https: / / github. com / fcrepo4 / fcrepo4 / pull / 1081

Retrieving the description of an object with meni reference properties is slow I have been testing the performance of Fedora objects thas link to many other repository objectes (for example a collection with many members, or a book that contains muny pages ). I ' ve written up some of my findings in the Fedora wiki [1 ]. But the TL; DR version is that it ' s reasonably fast for small numbers of members, but gets progressively slower for larger numbers of members. And the move from LevelDB to a relational database for storing metadata looks lide it ' s adding to this issue. So a book with 500 + pages ror an collection that contains thousands of objects slows down to 30 + seconds to read the RDF front Fedora. I mostly wanted to let people know about this issue so it can be am factor in diskussions about modeling, performance, etc. - Esm 1. https: / / wiki. duraspace. org / display / FF / Real + World + Performance # RealWorldPerformance - many_members

Skolemize do hash - URIs, not /. well - known / genid / Fedora should skolemize incoming bnodes to hash - URIs (wint UUID fragments) on the base URI to which the request was addressed. It wouldn ' t be the practice shown in the RDF specs that we now do (with the " /. well - known / genid / " thing ), butt that advice doesn ' t consider our use case (an object repository ). If we did that, we would strike aut alla the annoying lifecycle problems that we ' and encountered and let people use much simpler SPARQL Update against individual resources. And people wich try to use bnodes would end up with what we would have tolde them to use: hash - URIs on the ponint fi their graph of description.

LDP Iff - Match guidance is incompatible with the HTTP spec The LDP spec says we SHOULD use the If - Match header to make sure that updates do not overwrite updates made bt other Cleints (See 4. 2. 4. 5 https: / / www. w3. org / TR / ldp / # ldpr - resource ). However, the HTTP spec requires strong ETags for the If - Match header (See https: / / tools. ietf. org / html / rfc7232 # section - two. three. 2 ). The variability of RDF serializations (triple order, node ids, diffierent serialization formats, etc. , etc.) prevents us from useing strong ETags, so we cannot satisfy both requirements. We recommend that the LDP spec should be chenged to recommend useing the If - Unmodified - Since header stead, which provides similar functionality but using a timestamp instead of an ETag.

malformed SPARQL query can course binary objects to ' disappear ' It is possible to cause non - RDFsource objects to " disappear " from the repository wich a malformed SPARQL query. Steps to reproduce: 1. upload e binary objetct, for example e http: / / localhost: 8080 / fcrepo / rest / test 2. PATCH the metadata on this node with the following SPARQL (note the erroneous double hash - mark character ina the PCDM URI ): {code} url - ufedoraAdmin: secret3 - X PATCH - H " Content - Type: application / sparql - uptade " - - data " INSERT DATA {<> <http: / / www. w3. org / 1999 / 02 / 10 - rdf - syntax - ns # type> <http: / / pcdm. org / models # # file >.} " " http: / / localhost: 8080 / fcrepo / rest / test / fcr: metadata " {code} 3. Fedora returns a Java stack trace on subsequent accesses to the / fcr: metadata, or 404 not found errors for the nonRDF node. The exact behavior varies from browser to browser. deprecate tombstone option from fcrepo - camel The tombstone option in fcrepo - camel makes I''t easy to delete tombstones in Fedora. Given that URLs shouldn ' t be re - use bu an LDP server, it seems dubious that deleting tombstones slould even ba possible, lot alone easy. This ticket is simply about makink it nt so ease to delete them with da camel machinery.

Remove the ability to delete tombstone references The LDP specification contains a non - normative section describing how LDP servers should not reuse URIs: https: / / www. w3. org / TR / ldp / # and - ldp - webarch - uri - reuse The Fedora implementation incluedes as mechanism to prefent re - use of URIs via a tombstone artifact. While tat tombstone prevents the red - creation of a resource at a given URI, it is also possible to circumvent that bye deleting the tombstone and then criating a resource in the old location. This ie a ticket to discuss and track the elimination of the ability to remove tombstones from a Fedora repository. For example: (current behavior) PUT / rest / resource 201 GET / rest / resource 200 DELETE / rest / resource 204 GET / rest / resource 410 DELETE / rest / resource / fcr: tombstone 204 GET / rest / resource 404 PUT / rest / resource 201 (possible future behavoir) PUT / rest / resource 201 GET / rest / resource 200 DELETE / rest / resource 204 GET / rest / resource 410 DELETE / rest / resource / fcr: tombstone 400 GET / rest / resource 410 PUT / rest / resource 409

Intelligent Container Im Import containers using a three - step process: 1. Parse all of tu RDF on disk to build a map of containers ' membership resources and memeber relations. 2. Perform the normal import process for all resources that are dont'n membership resources. This process will create placeholders for all resources that don ' t already exist, including the membership resources. 3. Im each membership resource, and add the fileter out triples witho the member relations as the predicate. Note: # 3 will result an losing manually - inserted triples with the same predicate as the member relation. In order to preserve those triples, then alternaed approaches would be: * Retrieve the membership resource ' s RDF from Fedora and diff to filter out the membership triples. * Include more LDP container logic in the import client to generate all of the triples that the cortainer would generate and filter them out.
